title: Why do people hate split pushing
body:
> [{quoted}](name=LeagueSrsBsns,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=2NmkAhYd,comment-id=000500000001000000010000,timestamp=2015-02-13T10:13:35.986+0000)
>
> I hate this generalization so much. It literally made me go from a serious player to being viewed as a trick2g wannabe
> 
> when did split pushing become instantly associated with trick2g

Why do people hate split pushing Udyr who are "never with the team"
do they hate it because its a bad strategy? or is it cuz trick2g has given it a bad image?
What it means when you have a split pusher, 1 guy goes on a yolo tower killing spree as the rest of the team plays passively

if you're losing, shouldnt you be playing passively?
if you're winning? wouldnt a split pusher only end the game faster?
think logically for a sec... if you are perfectly aware that you are at a disadvantage in numbers and in gold, why do you do what you do? why risk throwing the game by forcing a team fight that you WILL LOSE

I do not know the perspective of my team but to me...
me abandoning them seems like the most logical choice to victory
5 man base turtle means

- no one can go out and ward
- no one can go out and secure objectives
- they get free barons and dragons and any other turret
- you make no advancement toward victory when all 5 of you are passively defending
- you're 100% under siege and cannot do anything unless you miraculously ace them
- the odds of the above are not likely if you are in fact losing

lets say you DO win the fight, what then? what can you do? kills dont win games.. objectives do
and their is too much pressure at your base to go off and secure an objective, dont you wish you had a split pusher to alleviate some beforehand?

am I wrong? is all mid the only path to victory?
can the other team afford to 5 v 4 my team as i take out their inhibitors anyway?
which brings me to the other point

if they send 1 person to stop me, i assuming I didnt kill him, would it not be 4 v 4?
if they dont send anyone to stop me, wouldnt I just win the game?

I find too many people have their judgment clouded in the heat of losing that anyone who is not sitting at base is not perceived as "helping"

replies.body:
People tend to dislike it because its the 'cheap' way to win. You're literally going for the win by ignoring everything that a team game stands for. You're saying "fuck you" not only to the enemy team, but your own team as well. Its essentially one of the most selfish actions there are. You're taking a PvP game and trying to make it PvE. Hell, they even have a term for it in DoTA 'Rat DoTA', because you're playing like a rat. You're sneaking around, chipping away until the enemy slowly crumbles. 
But I digress. The fundamental hatred of split pushing is a psychological issue all Mobas share. Yes, wiping their turrets out with Trynd and Nasus is a viable strategy. But theres a good reason no one will respect you for it.

this is interesting
I never thought about how people would hate split pushing because its a cheap way to win
I only noticed how we get alot of hate from being compared to trick or how we are never with the team

I kind of does have this "dick move" feel to it in my opinion. Especially when it is all they do and nothing else. Hell, we could be winning because of it, but I still get mad at the guy when they refuse help us team fight.

Well, think about you- you have a team that can win fights, mop up the enemy, and execute synergies very well. Normally, this would be enough to win you the game- but no, it isn't. Because the enemy Tryndamere has been split pushing all game long and just took an inhib while you were busy fighting. Which means you can't push off of your win, because now you and your team are locked inside your base for the next 4 minutes while the inhib respawns. If you ignore it, the super creeps kill your nexus. And during that time, the enemy team has free reign of the map, which leads to more towers/inhibs dropping because you just can't stop them. And suddenly, it doesn't matter that you were winning fights, because split push has made all of it a moot point.

It's nothing short of infuriating.

Yea well fact is that in a 5v5 teamfight there isn't much a single person can do to make sure their team gets the ace, making it hard to carry.

Splitpushing is an excellent strategy, and the only people I imagine crying about it are the ones that start 5-man camping mid at 13 minutes and sticking together as a 5-man group literally the rest of the game. Players like that should just stick to ARAM if they are going to cry about someone pushing lanes that they chose to ignore.

You wanna stick together the entire game for easy kills? Be my guest, I'm just gonna splitpush while the rest of my team hugs the inner turret and holds you off. Once you realize you're not yet strong enough to overpower the turret, I will already have taken your inhibitor. Doesn't matter if your team has 20 more kills than mine, I took 2 inhibitors while you were busy murdering my team and guess what? Inhibitors win games, not kills.

People who prefer teamfights see this as a fighting game, people who prefer splitpushing see this as a strategy game.

I will admit that their are situations where grouping is necessary, and there are situations where splitpushing is superior strategy, and a big part of being able to close out games as quickly as possible is knowing when to group and knowing when to split, but people who say "we need to teamfight at all times, we HAVE to ace them before we take objectives" will be in bronze forever.

Also, in solo q, people like to splitpush because often they hate their teammates, more than likely for a good reason.

> Yea well fact is that in a 5v5 teamfight there isn't much a single person can do to make sure their team gets the ace, making it hard to carry.

If everyone had that idea, teamfights would never happen. A team is more than just the sum of its parts. 

> You wanna stick together the entire game for easy kills? Be my guest, I'm just gonna splitpush while the rest of my team hugs the inner turret and holds you off. Once you realize you're not yet strong enough to overpower the turret, I will already have taken your inhibitor. Doesn't matter if your team has 20 more kills than mine, I took 2 inhibitors while you were busy murdering my team and guess what? Inhibitors win games, not kills.

And see, you just summed up my point PERFECTLY. My side worked as a team, while you're off there going "Me, myself, and I." Thats exactly why people hate it. Its an entirely selfish concept. You're not doing it for your team, you're doing it so YOU can have the glory, so YOU can say "Hey guys, I made us win!"And sure, I'm not saying winning isn't nice. But honestly? If my team worked together, did the best we could, and lost anyway? I'd take that any day.

> I will admit that their are situations where grouping is necessary, and there are situations where splitpushing is superior strategy, and a big part of being able to close out games as quickly as possible is knowing when to group and knowing when to split, but people who say "we need to teamfight at all times, we HAVE to ace them before we take objectives" will be in bronze forever.

There is a world of difference between "Hey guys, we're stagnating here, why don't we have someone shove the side lanes?" and "Hey guys, I'm going to be top all game, see ya." Also, I'm not one to pull rank normally, but maybe you shouldn't make judgements about 'bronze actions', when in bronze yourself. Seems kind of...ironical. 

> Also, in solo q, people like to splitpush because often they hate their teammates, more than likely for a good reason.

Contrary to popular belief, most people do NOT hate their teammates. In fact, most of the time, they work together nicely. Especially as you climb in elos, you'll find that people realize that for better or worse, this is the team you've been given. If you want to win, may as well work with them.
More back to the point though, people in solo que tend to splitpush because they see an opportunity (bait or not), or they're playing as a champion that they believe exists for splitpushing (Trynd, Nasus, Malz, etc).

Unless the split-pusher has permission and the team adjusts their gameplay to allow it? It's a strategy that either forces the enemy team to split up and send someone to defend, or the team gets objectives while turtling. In a team game, you have to use tactics and work together. You don't have to be grouped up all the time to get things done, and sometimes you have to trust one another. Using strategy and trusting one another IS part of a team game. If someone just goes off willy-nilly to split-push, then that's selfish. But if the team decides it's a good idea, then there's nothing wrong with it. 

A team that's behind has a lower chance of winning a teamfight than the one ahead (assuming team comp has roughly the same synergy), so it's not always wise to force one.

The idea behind split pushing is that the team can go even on a 4v5 at that point. If you don't think your team can handle it the split push is not necessarily a good idea.

The split push can be considered in several ways:

1: A top laner with teleport can easily rejoin a fight which starts at the opposite side of the map. This is a big reason why we see teleport so often.

2: A player with a lot of dueling potential requires at least two players to take down. If they send two players then the other lane is a 4v3, but if they don't send anyone the split pusher takes objectives.

Whether split pushing is a good idea or not mostly depends on team comp and player skill.

There are multiple problems when trying to split push in low elo games.  The idea of split pushing (as many have said) is to have one player (like Udyr) who can 1v1 anyone on the other team split from the team and push some objectives while the rest of the team tries to not have a team fight.  For this to work the rest of the team has to give enough pressure that the opposing team can't just use the whole team to collapse on the split pusher and kill him.  But they also need to be able to disengage fights.

1. Most low elo teams don't know how occupy the other team with the remaining 4 players while also avoiding a fight.  The result is either the opposing team collapses on the split pusher and kills him or there is a teamfight without the split pusher.

2. Many low elo split pushers will try to split push when it is impossible for the 4 remaining players to occupy the other team and avoid a teamfight (they have poor disengage and/or the opponents have really good engage).  The result is the same as the previous reason.
